case_vignette: A 16-year-old female presents to her pediatrician’s office because she has not yet started menstruating. On review of systems, she states that she has been increasingly tired, constipated, and cold over the last 6 months. She also endorses a long history of migraines with aura that have increased in frequency over the last year. She complains that these symptoms have affected her performance on the track team. She states that she is not sexually active. Her mother and sister both underwent menarche at age 15. The patient is 5 feet, 4 inches tall and weighs 100 pounds (BMI 17.2 kg/m^2). Temperature is 98.4°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 98/59 mmHg, pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 14/min. On exam, the patient appears pale and has thinning hair. She has Tanner stage IV breasts and Tanner stage III pubic hair.
question: Which  would be most useful in determining this patient’s diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Endocrinology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been feeling really tired, constipated, and cold a lot over the past six months.
Have you noticed any weight gain or changes in your appetite during this time?
No, I haven't noticed any weight gain or changes in my appetite.

Do you have a family history of thyroid issues?

**Final Diagnosis:** Hypothyroidism (if family history is positive, consider Hashimoto's thyroiditis) or Subclinical Hypothyroidism (if no family history) based on symptoms. Further testing would be needed for confirmation.
